definition:
Bloch’s theorem can be stated in the following way:

Let $\mathcal{F}$ be the set of all functions $f$ holomorphic on a
region containing the closure of the disk $D=\{z\in\mathbb{C}:|z|<1\}$
and satisfying $f(0)=0$ and $f'(0)=1$. For each $f\in\mathcal{F}$ let
$\beta(f)$ be the supremum of all numbers $r$ such that there is a disk
$S\subset D$ on which $f$ is injective and $f(S)$ contains a disk of
radius $r$. Let $B$ be the infimum of all $\beta(f)$, for $f\in
\mathcal{F}$. Then $B\geq 1/72$.

The constant $B$ is usually referred to as Bloch’s constant. Nowadays,
better bounds are known and, in fact, it has been conjectured that $B$
has the following tantalizing form
$$B=\frac{\Gamma(1/3)\cdot \Gamma(11/12)}{\left(\sqrt{1+\sqrt{3}}\right)\cdot \Gamma(1/4)}$$
where $\Gamma(x)$ is the gamma function.

[00]{}

John B. Conway, [*Functions of One Complex Variable I*]{}, Second
Edition, 1978, Springer-Verlag, New York.
